Patch Set 21:

(5 comments)

Good mechanical change, use of "sensorCommon" makes it easier to read, as the common code stands out more. I am concerned about feature creep of this very large patch, however. I would limit it to just the sensorCommon refactoring. Avoid pollRate and fan PWM numbering path changes. The pollRate feature and the fan feature should both be their own separate changes.

Patch Set 21:

(5 comments)

Thank you for taking the time to simplify the design. Move to has-a relationship does make many things cleaner. But, there are many "almost" duplicate code/function in this package that seem like can be simplified with abstraction and inheritance. Is that some thing you have in mind as a follow up step?

I would limit it to just the sensorCommon refactoring. Avoid pollRate and fan PWM numbering path changes. The pollRate feature and the fan feature should both be their own separate changes.

Agreed, but I think you're looking at the diff wrong, and you're seeing all the rebased-in changes that have been merged into this repo recently.  You might want to set your gerrit to compare this patchset to master, not this patchset to its previous self.

I'm interested to know what your thoughts are here, but we should probably have that discussion on the mailing list or on discord, not on this patchset, unless this patchset is in direct opposition to what you're thinking.

I'm not really sure what to do with this patch.  Testing is going to be hard, and as it's already starting to have bad merge conflicts.  There also wasn't a great way to break it up considering that we're de-virtualizing a class that nearly every sensor uses.  Overall I think this is a good change, I'm just not sure how to get it in without breaking people.

Can you not split your approach? Have the class that implements the composable approach inherit from the current sensor base class, then convert the specific sensors as separate, incremental patches? Then once you've completed the conversion as independent patches, do whatever cleanup you want to the new composable sensor class?

That might actually work.......  I didn't think about just inventing a new class temporarily.  Glad I asked.
Is there something unique about ExitAirTempSensor that makes it still require std::enable_shared_from_this()? The other sensor daemons do not.
A forward declaration! :)

I didn't write it, and it's a sign that this file needs refactored. 😊

In theory, I don't think assertThresholds needs the Sensor object itself, just a couple of fields from it, which would fix this forward declaration.

It should be noted, this is also clogging up the global namespace, which is equally as bad.


ps, the irony here is that you actually pointed out the design issue (taking sensor by reference in a timer) that caused this to have to be forward declared.  If this code were submitted today, I probably wouldn't accept it.
Good to know, makes sense.

What is the lifetime of this? Member variables that are references always make me uneasy. Especially when they are used in a lambda passed elsewhere. Do we guarantee Boost won't call it after the lifetime ends?

> What is the lifetime of this?

Longer than the lifetime of the ThresholdTimer class

> Member variables that are references always make me uneasy.

Agreed.  I'm not in love with this one, but this is no worse than it was before, and in normal use (putting a ThresholdTimer within a sensor instance) the lifetimes are correct, even if it's easy to get wrong if this were a generic thing.  It's ripe for improvement if you wanted to refactor it.

> Especially when they are used in a lambda passed elsewhere. Do we guarantee Boost won't call it after the lifetime ends?

Yes, this is one of boost asios guarantees.  Some others are:
1. All async operations callback handlers will be called exactly once per async_* call.
2. On destruction of the underlying object, the callback will be called from the destructor with an "operation aborted" error message.

Interesting. As for #2 above, despite the supposed design guarantee, I remember we finding this wasn't seeming to be happening as intended. In PSUSensor, there were strange crashes/misbehaviors that would happen if the sensors were reloaded during the run, and this was because Boost was calling stale callbacks after their underlying objects had been destroyed. The workaround was to add weak_ptr that would stretch the lifetime if needed, and cleanly let the callback become a no-op once it realized that its underlying object had already been destroyed by the time it was called: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/30763

> Interesting. As for #2 above, despite the supposed design guarantee, I remember we finding this wasn't seeming to be happening as intended. In PSUSensor, there were strange crashes/misbehaviors that would happen if the sensors were reloaded during the run, and this was because Boost was calling stale callbacks after their underlying objects had been destroyed.

Yep.  The root cause of this is that Sensor is destroyed in the wrong order, and because it owns callbacks on the super class, might get called back on memory that no longer exists.  Having Sensor as a member variable instead of an inherited class actually gives us some ability to fix this, although I suspect fixing the check_thresholds thing probably fixes a lot of stuff.

> The workaround was to add weak_ptr that would stretch the lifetime if needed, and cleanly let the callback become a no-op once it realized that its underlying object had already been destroyed by the time it was called: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/30763

Yep, I recall that fix.  IMO it's a bit of a bandaid, as the ownership model is still wrong, it's just no longer fatal with the weak_ptr stuff, and you're forcing shared ownership on some things that really don't need it.

Once this lands, looking at the ownership model is on my short list to go look at here.

This is good timing. We discovered crashes from adcsensor due to threshold and threshold timer lifetime issue also. Using the weak_ptr approach fixed it. But the patch was ugly. Refactor and cleanup the ownership would be a cleaner approach.

Does this patchset fix them?  Also, good timing is relative, this patchset has been hanging around for a loooooong time.

Any testing you could help give would be great.  I don't have as many systems as I once did.

I like this syntax! Using a lambda inline avoids having to make a dummy function. It also can be replaced, like any other member variable, without having to use inheritance. And good to rename it as well, to make it easy to catch all previous usages.

However, shouldn't there be something like the below in the constructor of each sensor daemon's WhateverSensor object?
sensor.checkThresholdsFunc = [this]() { this->checkThresholds(); };

I see this for most, but not all, sensor daemons. Have all existing usages of checkThresholds() been audited?

> I like this syntax! Using a lambda inline avoids having to make a dummy function. It also can be replaced, like any other member variable, without having to use inheritance. And good to rename it as well, to make it easy to catch all previous usages.

> 
> However, shouldn't there be something like the below in the constructor of each sensor daemon's WhateverSensor object?
> sensor.checkThresholdsFunc = [this]() { this->checkThresholds(); };

Yes, there should.  If I missed one, it's a mistake.

> 
> I see this for most, but not all, sensor daemons. Have all existing usages of checkThresholds() been audited?

At the time I originally authored this patch, I thought I had covered all of them, but it's quite possible I messed it up somewhere in one of the rebases.  I'll take another look.
I'm curious why the new syntax, and why it needs to be laundered through a tuple. What advantage does this bring, versus the increase in the difficulty of understanding what it does?

This is a long story, but the short version is:

Because of the way dbus interfaces work, old sensors with the same name need to be destroyed before the new sensor is created.  Originally this code was something like

gCpuSensors[sensorName] = std::make_unique<CPUSensor>....

Which is exactly what a sane person would write.  In practice, this caused a really bad bug, where on reconfigure events, dbus would see.

Sensor Foo added sensor.value interface

Then later on a reconfigure
Sensor Foo added sensor.value interface
Sensor Foo removed sensor.value interface


Even though the sensor is still alive, the second add happened before the first remove, so the mapper removes it, and the sensor disappears.

To combat this, James wrote the code on the left, which destroys the old object (thus sending the removed events) explicitly before creating the new object.  He only had to do this because him and I stared at the compiler for several hours, and couldn't figure out the syntax to do an in-place replace of an object, rather than a construct and a move.

The code below, is the code we couldn't figure out at the time (turns out it needed c++14).   While complicated, is simpler in execution, and does exactly what we want here, destroys the old sensor object if it exists, and constructs a new one, all in one step.

As far as why it needs to use tuple, that's a question for the standards committee.  I'm sure they had their reasons.

OK, wow, that is pretty deep. Perhaps add the above note in a comment? I didn't know the below code would make a difference with respect to sequencing:  that it could change how the container works, to destroy the old sensor, and unmap it, then add the new sensor, and map it, in the proper sequence.

I can add a comment.  Technically the old code had a kind of OK comment, so best not to go backwards.

ACK.
Does it still require a std::move() of the lambda object, when passing it into setupSensorMatch() here? I am curious why the old code used std::move() but the new code no longer does.

in this usage the lambda is already an rvalue.  std::move is meant to turn an lvalue into an rvalue, so wrapping this in std::move does nothing here, except add code.  This throws a warning in clang-tidy, because it's clear you intended something, but you operated on the wrong thing.

It should be noted, I really wish they had made this a compiler error in the c++ standard, but I'm sure they had their reasons.
OK, makes sense. The idea of moving (versus copying) was added late in the language's syntax development, and it shows.
I'm curious, with all the recent refactoring of pointers into references, should dbusConnection also be similarly refactored?
OK, makes sense.
Curious why this renaming, it doesn't seem to change anything except the name, and creates a substantial blast radius below.

because all sensors now have a "sensor" member, this was a shadowed variable, which the compiler flagged, and had to be renamed to something that didn't shadow.  I could've named all the other sensor member variables to something different, but changing this seemed like it would keep more consistency between sensors.

The name "sensor" does seem to be a rather simplistic name, for such an important object that's a long-lived member variable. If it were me, I would have called it "sensorBase" or "sensorImpl" or "sensorMain" or "sensorCommon" instead. This would also solve the name clash we see here, with local variables also named "sensor".

I prefer to use simple all-lowercase words for temporaries and local variables instead, as the original code did here when it allocated a new Sensor object.

> The name "sensor" does seem to be a rather simplistic name, for such an important object that's a long-lived member variable. If it were me, I would have called it "sensorBase"

SensorBase implies it's a base class, which it is not.

> or "sensorImpl"

SensorImpl implies it's an implementation of a virtual class, which it is not.

> or "sensorMain"

SensorMain makes it collide with all the main() method filenames (PSUSensorMain, ect).  

> or "sensorCommon"

This name I can get behind.  Will fix.

> instead. This would also solve the name clash we see here, with local variables also named "sensor".
> 
> I prefer to use simple all-lowercase words for temporaries and local variables instead, as the original code did here when it allocated a new Sensor object.

unfortunately the coding standard doesn't have any such preference, but it's certainly something to consider for the future.
Done

Does PSUSensor require std::enable_shared_from_this anymore? I remember some complicated code that was added earlier, to clean up ownership and deal with lingering callbacks. I wonder if that complicated code is still necessary, now that "sensor" is a member and no longer subclassed.
How is use of dangling reference prevented?

I'm assuming you mean a reference that points to memory that has been destroyed.  The answer to that is largely "it doesn't".

It DOES make the memory ownership model cleaner, and gives us more control over the destructor order which should be the start of some of this stuff becoming cleaner, but this patch isn't the end all be all of patches, and doesn't fix every possible issue, it mostly just sets us up for being able to simplify this stuff further, which will clean up some ownership issues between the sensor class and the super class.

If you're interested, I'm happy to hear more about your ideas here.
I am doing some research on this. I will share when I have something more solid.
Great, looking forward to it.

Well, the solution for detecting dangling reference, where the referenced objects have been deleted, is smart pointers. I tried few things, could not come up with a simpler and cleaner solution. More details added with the code change line.

I am still relatively new to dbus. So this is just a question for my own education.
Will there be problems if the new sensor is constructed with the same name, path, interfaces etc. before the old sensor is destructed? What happens if another service comes along and uses object mapper to get managed objects before the old sensor instance get destructed?

> I am still relatively new to dbus. So this is just a question for my own education.
> Will there be problems if the new sensor is constructed with the same name, path, interfaces etc. before the old sensor is destructed?

Yes, this was a very non-obvious bug that james and I found.  If you see something like

sensors[sensorName] = nullptr;
sensors.emplace(sensorName, Sensor{...{});

That was us trying to fix it.  Modern code should use emplace directly, and construct the new sensor in place, instead of constructing via std::move.

In theory objectmanager could detect this and prevent the signal from going out (or destroy the old interface before adding the new one) but I haven't looked at that.

> What happens if another service comes along and uses object mapper to get managed objects before the old sensor instance get destructed?

You get the old interface behavior.  We've done our best in this code to try to avoid that problem by properly destroying the old objects before creating new ones with the same path.  There might still be outliers though.

There are changes that affect sensors and thresholds lifetime. I am little concerned of potential new race conditions.
Maybe test with randomized scan/rescan (construct and destruct) for sensors?

I've done a few tests like that here, but I don't have as many daemons running on my systems, so I'm not able to sus out all the possible races.

With that said, I think I've covered them as best as I'm able.

If you could help test, that would be great.
I will do some testing and share result in next couple days.

I found that adcsensor service crashes when I changed the threshold with the following commands:
*P3VBAT threshold (0x50 sensor number from ipmitool sdr elist)
ipmitool raw 0x04 0x27 0x50  //read sensor value
ipmitool raw 0x04 0x26 0x50 0x1b 0x99 0x6b 0x00 0xa4 0xa6 0x00  //set threshold 3.04
ipmitool raw 0x04 0x26 0x50 0x1b 0x95 0x6b 0x00 0xa4 0xa6 0x00  //set threshold 2.97

I have added comments at the code change locations
Should we prefer std to boost going forward?

It depends on your needs.  In this case, CPUSensor doesn't allow move (yet), so I needed a container that didn't need move semantics on insert.  I'd normally use flat_map here just to keep the memory usage lower, as we don't care about insert/find performance.
So not all enable_shared_from_this are removed, as indicated in the commit message?
Need to match the dbus interface here, right?  There are other places too.
Yeah, this looks a lot like a bad search/replace.

Still need use weak_ptr to prevent invalid access after this is destructed.
When async calls are aborted because of sensor destruction, already queued work may exist and not removed.

> Still need use weak_ptr to prevent invalid access after this is destructed.
> When async calls are aborted because of sensor destruction, already queued work may exist and not removed.

if we ensure that waitTimer is destroyed before "this" (ie ADCSensor), then this code will callback before the sensor is destroyed, and therefore be valid.  What's interesting, is this code looks right

Ok, I see the real problem here.  InputDev is owned by AdcSensor, but is calling into sensorCommon.  in theory, if we move sensorCommon to be declared above inputDev in the .h file, that should clear this up.


With that said, i'll do that in another patch.  Thanks for helping test.
If abort is caused by destruction, will "this" be invalid?
yes, good point.  I missed that.  I'll put in a new patch.
This would construct the new one first and then destruct the obsolete one, right? If true, there would be a tiny window that both new sensor and old sensor exist. Will dbus be confused?

emplace will not replace the existing one with the newly constructed sensor.
insert_or_assign can ensure the old one is replaced.
But, there is still the issue that for a tiny time window, there are two sensor objects with identical path and name on the bus.
sensors.erase(sensorName) can be added at line 272, then emplace can be kept here.
yeah, this is totally wrong.  Will go back to the old one.
add check if(it.second) {}
If this were kept as emplace, you'd be right, but with this moving to insert_or_assign, won't this still be needed?
It looks like a lot of changes took place here and below, with respect to PWM numbering and string path building. I am curious why? The old code worked, and was well tested.

This patchset has been rebased.  I suspect you looked at the diff between patchset 1 and patchset N.  If you compare patchset N to master, this has no diff.

With that said, happy to discuss outside the context of this patchset if you think this is wrong.
Thanks, you're correct.
Perhaps group this constant with the others in HwmonTempSensor.cpp file?
Yes, this was because I looked at an earlier patchset instead of the base. Good to know the base has been updated, to result in less conflict.
Curious why float used here, not double.
This isn't part of the diff.  Happy to talk about this out of band.
Thanks, I see it now, good that there's no changes against the base.
The pollRate feature is new, not merely a code cleanup. As such, it will benefit from being in a second change. This change is already rather large.
Pollrate was added in a different patch.  Please diff patchset N to master, not patchset 1 to patchset N.
Got it.
Multiplying floating-point should multiply by 1000.0

Agreed, although this is equally as correct

With that said, see previous notes, I think you looked at the wrong diff.
Yep, although 1000.0 is clearer and it prevents the compiler from wrongly casting it to integer too early. As you said, though, that's not the subject of this patch.
